title: Do you want to become a K-pop idol? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ll be honest here. Of course, you need the basic things. Like talent and skill. But the entertainment business is shady, so you also need a number of other things which are kind of unusual. Talent No one can make it in without talent. But there are cases when people aren’t all that talented but are accepted because of the obvious passion, dedication, potential and beauty. You have to have a good voice and be able to dance properly. If you excel in at least one field, you are probably gonna make it in. For example, RM of BTS isn’t that good in dance. But his rap makes up for it. Visual This may seem harsh, but you have really less chances of making it in without visuals. Especially in the bigger agencies, like SM, they prize visuals. I won’t say that it’s the inner beauty that matters, even though this phrase is true, it’s BS for this world. But I can say that everyone is beautiful. But what they will judge you on will be based off of how attractive you are too. Some people are turned down the moment they walk in all because they were unattractive. You have to meet Korea’s beauty standards or just be attractive in general. I’ve heard many people say that they will still accept you if you are talented. Which is kind of true but now, I can say that it’s only true for some cases. Visuals do matter. In this day and age, it’s as if it’s socially unacceptable for “ugly” people to do anything. Basically, you have to be attractive. Personality If you wanna be an idol, then you have to have a persona, or just a bubbly personality in general. People will most likely look down on idols with a more quiet, offensive, sensual and/or different personality. To be completely honest, fan service includes your personality and the way you present yourself. Fans won’t accept it if you aren’t smiling at them 24/7. Having a bad day? Oh, that doesn’t even matter, you still will have to smile. A more outgoing, bubbly, chaotic, cute, extroverted and innocent personality is what is attractive for the public, so they will accept you and love you. If you aren’t like that, then you will have to wear a mask at all times just to please your fans. Basically, it’s being a people pleaser and changing yourself for the sake of others. Tolerance The trainee system, diet, practice, sleepless nights and near to no privacy is really hard to handle and can drive a person crazy. I can’t live without sleeping for at laeast 8 hours, eating lots and having privacy. So it’ll be hard for someone like me to be able to tolerate everything that comes with fame. You are over-exposed as an idol. The schedule is insane. The diets are unhealthy. But, you can’t break down. People won’t really accept an idol who isn’t smiling, isn't looking happy and is complaining about their schedules. You have to hide it with a smile, it’s hard to oppose the system and have people support you. If you have one bad day and don’t feel like carrying on, people won’t accept it. All because you are a public figure. Just put the word idol into a sentence, and peope will expect you to be alright and be tolerant at all times. Groups like BTS are lucky to have fans like the majority of ARMY. ARMY accepted it when BTS would cry, be going through a hard time or just be not into the day. The fans don’t say that “it’s their duty to not show their dissatisfication as they are a public figure.” But, not everyone is like that, and people will always find things to criticize. Basically, without patience and tolerance, you will break down. And if you break down, people will hate on you, treat you like being an idol you have to be happy 24/7, won’t accept it and treat you like you are arrogant. And if you are hated on, you will break down further. It’s necessary to have tolerance. Be An Artist There’s a fine line between an artist and an idol. An artist is someone whose involved in the music they make. Some examples are Hui of Pentagon, LE of EXID, BTS, Jessi and 3RACHA. And people who are just an idol, are people like Blackpink, EXO, TWICE and a few other SM idols. Now, I accept it if you don’t songwrite, produce or compose your own songs. But I also prefer idols to be involved in their work, so whatever they sing about is coming from the heart, and many nights were sacrificed to make it yourself with the help of others. And, to be honest, I wouldn’t really want to Stan a group who isn’t involved in their work. I just prefer idols to be artists but I do accept the other side too. But nowadays, people hate on idols who aren’t involved in their work. A lot of people hate on idols who don’t songwrite. And they also call them untalented. That’s just extra turmoil and no one will want to go through that. So it’s best to learn how to songwrite/produce/compose so people will accept and respect you.

I’ve been struggling with these few words for a couple of months now: I want to be a K-Pop Idol- But… I want to be a K-Pop Idol. I truly do. The feeling is welling up inside of me, a dream, a wish, a hope that I want more than anything right now. I’m willing to give up everything. My privacy, my time, I would put everything I have into it. I know that I have the determination. When I start something, I finish it. I absolutely love working until I can’t, I absolutely love pushing myself past my limits. I love music more than anything, I always have. I have musical talent in my family. Music inspires me. Music is me. I’ve always loved music in every way. Especially dance. And ever since I’ve gotten into K-Pop, I’ve been learning dance after dance, technique after technique, I’m even spending the time and money for a professional trainer that worked with Girls Generation and Psy. I’m putting my everything into my dream. But I don’t know why, because the fact is, I will never be a K-Pop idol. Now, you’re going to tell me as I’ve heard from my friends, “Well, with that attitude, no you won’t. It sounds like you’ve got the time and money, and determination to live your dreams. I bet you could!” But I can’t. And it’s not my decision. So let me start with my first reason. My religion/culture isn’t against, but strongly tries to keep us away from showy clothing, plastic surgery, etc. I think all the rules and restrictions of being a trainee and an idol will be against what I believe in. People ask me, “Just forget about your rules. You can do what you want. Nothing is stopping you. If you follow your rules and don’t become an idol, well that’s your fault.” And I guess that’s true. But on to the next problem, that I can’t control no matter what, is that I can’t diet. I’ve got a health restraint that I can’t go into detail about. I could diet, but in no way, shape, or form would it work how they want. Heck, I’d have to write that on my audition form, I’m guessing, and they’d turn me down right away. If not, once they realized, they’d kick me out for sure. I can’t go into detail, but there’s no way any diet, even if it’s very specific to what I need will get me where they want me, without hurting me worse and making me unable to do anything at all. I guess this is my biggest problem, verses the other one. Lastly, I can’t sing. I guess I’d learn from them if I got in just because of my talent in dancing, but I hear a lot that you have to sing as well. At least a bit. Hey, I’m not the worst, but I’m not specifically talented in singing in any way. I’d probably be a rapper, but I just don’t know… I think most K-Pop fans want this, they have this dream, wish, hope, just as I do. The thought that I’d have a group that I’d perform with, dancing and singing my heart out, giving people hope is what I want in this life. I don’t care about the fame. I want to be like my idol, J-Hope from BTS. I want to give people a reason to smile, no matter what. I want to bring people the joy he brings me. All I’ve ever wanted in my life is to help others, to bring them joy. That is my ultimate goal. And becoming a K-Pop idol, I hope would help me do that. And people tell me that I just want K-Pop because I am a fan myself, but I really like how Korea does groups, and it’s not just singing, but dancing and rapping. I want to do K-Pop, but I can’t. I can’t. I know the consequesnces. I know what you have to give up. I know the pain. I know being a trainee isn’t everything you imagine. It’s enough for me. I still want it. I’ve put in a lot of consideration. I know what it takes and I’m willing. A lot of people who made answers on this question say that they grew out of it. They grew out of their dream. Maybe I will, but I honestly hope not. My hope right now is that I’ll find some opportunity here in America where I can do something with dance, music, and performing. Something close enough. I might have a chance since America isn’t as strict. That is my hope. I will always love K-Pop, but I don’t have a chance with the industry. So, I hope America can give me the same joy. That’s the only thing that keeps me going right now because my dream to be a K-Pop idol still burns inside of me like fire, it’s so strong. And it hurts that I can’t be a K-Pop idol. I just hope America can give me the same joy. And if I do grow out of this dream, I’ve got other talents and things I wanted before I got into K-Pop. So I have a pretty good future ahead, I guess. We’ll see. So to answer your question, yes, I do really want to be a K-Pop idol. Will I? No. Can I? No. But I’m going to look on the bright side, and once again, hopefully America can give me the same joy in one way or another. If anyone thinks they have advice for me, I’d appreciate it a lot. Thanks, and I hope this answers your question.

No, I wouldn't want to be a Kpop star at all. I mean, I think everyone once imagined to be popular and famous and rich once when they were young, but now that I know the consequences of being famous, I wouldn't dream of becoming a star. Yes, having fans shout out your name as they fantasize about meeting you in person, people asking for your autograph, your albums being bought every-so hour is fascinating. You get money, fame, and love. But there's also bad causes to this. First you need to sign a contract with whatever label. You have to dedicate your whole time in the whole recording the songs, practicing the choreography, making the MVS, having to go to concerts, dealing with super possessive fans, having to meet the dead line, watching your diet, making sure you have the right style, having to be careful out in public, all these hours spent on something that can go down at any second for something so small. For example, you're out somewhere on live TV and you say something but people mistake it to a whole different meaning. Next thing you know, you're in social media with so many people criticizing you for something you did not mean. All that hard work goes down the toilet for just a misunderstanding. So much time goes by trying to raise to the top, when you can spent your precious time with family and friends. Free from cameras and paparazzi, you can go out in the street in your pj’s and not have to worry about someone commenting on your choice of style. I'm not saying that Kpop Stars deal with such slavery work, but they don't have the life of a normal citizen, they deal with do much crap, it's stressful. I can barely go without a day of complaints. I whine about homework, when these Kpop stars have to deal with getting the right pitch and lyrics for their songs, need to dance to “perfection”, be able to deal with fans. I just can't do that. Kpop stars also have to deal with training. It can take years for me to finally debut (exaggeration). Patience is not one of my virtues. And then not being able to see my parents for who knows how long?! Nope. That's a definite No-No right there. I have to see my mom everyday. So my answer is a definite no. Being able to be on screen and having my name being chanted by millions of people, sounds great. But being able to stay home in my cozy room with my mom and dress like a slob whenever I want to, sounds much better

depends on what you mean, either if you wanna be a Kpop idol, or just someone involved in Kpop musically. If you meant the former, then of course, you have to audition. But auditioning means you either have to have: Talent- which is the main reason for being a performer/ idol. You either have to be good at what you’re doing, and by good I mean exceptionally good because there are a lot of people aiming for what you are and doing what you’re gonna do, and sometimes, there are going to be people much more better than you. But of course, don’t lose hope. Maybe you’ll just be what the company is looking for. Visuals- you’re good-looking by Korean standards and you have decent talent even if you’re not good at it. They’ll take you in if you fit their style and you have potential lol. See Seventeen’s Mingyu, for example. The guy literally got scouted while he was out playing soccer and auditioned with SLIPPERS ON WHILE SINGING THE KOREAN NATIONAL ANTHEM (istg i hate him so much lmfao) but guess what? he’s handsome and the CEO liked him so he’s in BUT he improved himself and can now sing, dance, and is one of the group’s rappers and is an emcee in Music Core now. So even if you look good, you gotta put effort to actually know how to do something or else you’ll get hated on. But all idols get hated on by someone so better lessen the haters while you have the chance lol Mingyu rapping for reference:  so either of the two, or connections. connections are eVERytHIng in any industry tbh So you auditioned. Great! But wow. are there a lot more people. Bluntly, there will be people 10X better than you, but seriously, it all boils down to luck. If the company likes you, even if the other guy was better than you in all areas, then lucky you ! you’re in! not as a trainee. but in the 2nd round of auditions lol Auditions have normally 3 rounds. Public. Private.Then a very long Interview. If you pass all those, you’re a trainee! But the training process is much more harder than the audition process along with years of training every day and you’re not even sure if you’re gonna debut. Which is scary and nerve-wracking. But if you wanna dedicate your teenage years to something that you really wanna do then why not? But heed my advice: ALWAYS HAVE A PLAN B Companies may kick you out if you don’t improve in your skills enough or if they’re wondering why you’re even there. And the training process is a literal jungle, if the company is planning to debut a group, then expect The Hunger Games to happen every man for himself regardless of your relationships. Why? Because you came there to debut and to become an idol. I can go on and on but I’m sleepy and that’s all I’ve got so far. If you wanna be an idol, train hard before auditioning and stand out. That’s all I gotta say. Dm me for more questions! Anyway, good luck if you wanna be an idol!! <3

Are you asking specifically if a boy, as in, a child, can become K-Pop idol? Or are you asking if a male Korean can become an idol? Please specify in future questions if you want a genuine answer. IF YOU ARE A MALE AND YOU WANT TO BECOME A K-POP IDOL There are hundreds of male K-Pop idols. I can name a few groups just off the top of my head- BTS, EXO- Monsta X, GOT7, etc. And those are just a few of the more popular ones. Yes, it is possible for you to become a K-Pop idol. IF YOU WANT TO KNOW IF A CHILD CAN BECOME A K-POP IDOL I personally haven’t heard about young children becoming K-Pop idols, since it requires hard training and often brutal workouts, and I doubt some of the bigger companies are able (or willing) to take care of a 7 year old’s needs. The youngest I’ve ever heard an idol to be at debut was 14 years old. And even then they’d started training at a younger age, usually around 13. IF YOU (OR SOMEONE ELSE) WANTS TO BECOME A K-POP IDOL I am not going to sugarcoat this. K-Pop is a dark, dark industry. If you don’t have true dedication, then your chances are at zero. Many trainees who truly love music have to leave because it is taking too much of a toll on their bodies. There are many people who want to become a K-Pop idol just so they can meet their favorite groups (BTS, EXO, BLACKPINK, just to name a few), maybe even hope to date/marry. If you want to become an idol for this reason, it is highly doubtful that you will make it, since even for Koreans, it takes a lot of true dedication to music to be able to debut. Also, many companies have precautions to prevent harassment. It isn’t impossible to become a K-Pop idol, even if you don’t have the standard Korean looks. However, there are a number of factors that can contribute to whether or not you’d be successful: Are you Asian? There are a number of Chinese and Japanese K-Pop idols, along with some Taiwanese. However, these people tend to receive more hate, just because they’re not from the same culture. If you’re not at least partly Asian, the chances of you making it grow slimmer.Can you speak Korean? This is perhaps the biggest one. If you can’t, you most likely won’t make it.How good is your dancing/singing/rapping? No matter how pretty you are, if you can’t dance, sing, or rap decently, the chances of you making it are slim, unless you’re hoping to join as a visual.Are you ready for intense training? K-Pop idols don’t become famous overnight. I can’t emphasize this enough. IT IS NOT ALL FUN AND GAMES. We only see their good side, the happy side. On the other side of the screen, there may be bullying, suicidal thoughts, and tears, and we would never know. The training they go through is so intense, and many companies treat their idols like trash, so never mind about the trainees.Something else you should worry about is how you will convince companies to accept you as a trainee. This is not racism or prejudice- it’s the simple fact that they need to eat and feed their family. They need to worry about whether you’d be successful, because if you don’t, their reputation becomes tainted. RANT I might’ve sounded rude at some points during writing this, but that’s because I’m tired of people who just want to become K-Pop idols because they think that they’ll be famous, they’ll get to be friends with their favorite stars, everyone will love them, all they need to have is a pretty face. NO! It takes years for idols to train, and then some ignorant people come along and act like it’s nothing. They work their butts off trying to please their fans, to produce good quality content, and they often starve themselves. My friend told me that she wanted to become an idol under Big Hit so she could marry BTS. Too many people think that it takes just a nice voice to become a star, that it happens overnight. And it doesn’t. APOLOGIES IF I OFFENDED ANYONE, BUT I MEANT EVERY WORD I SAID. GOOD DAY.

Do I want to become a K-Pop idol? YES. Yes, I do. Ever since I found out about BTS, I always admired their charisma, amazing talent, and the love that they show to their fans. But I thought that if I were to become someone like them (female version) will I even be able to become so high up, praised and inspiring? Over time, I realised that BigHit does not do female groups, but even if they did, I would’ve been too much of a coward to even apply. Why? Because I felt like I wasn’t good enough, I would embarrass myself, and I was afraid to be judged negatively. Then, I got interested in Blackpink. They are my favourite girl group. I became inspired by them, each one of them had an impact on my dream to become an idol. I wanted to be just like them, good at dance, good at singing/rapping, have charisma, be beautiful like them, and be inspiring. But there were certain things that stopped me from actually believing in myself. I cannot perform on stage very well, especially if it is by myself (because I get nervous and instantly feel like people are laughing at me on the inside).I do not think I am good looking enough or fit enough to audition.I do not believe I am talented enough.I don’t believe I am good enough in general.I don’t know Korean (I’m from Australia, also an Australian Born Chinese).I am not a very out-going and confident person. I was bullied in primary school, but now that I moved to high school, things are better. But the bullying had a huge impact on my self-esteem. I am constantly judging myself either for my body, face or both. But at the same time, I wanted to become an idol SO FREAKING BAD. I wanted to inspire people, to show people that I can be good enough, to be confident and to do what makes me happy. I don’t know why, but I was sort of ashamed to admit that I wanted to become a K-pop idol. Maybe it was the fact that I thought that people thought I was pathetic? Or maybe it was the fact that I thought I was pathetic MYSELF? Both? I knew that it wasn’t just that simple to become an idol. The first step is to audition, and if you get accepted, HALLELUJAH. But then you have to fight to be at the top, you have to train, work hard, and follow strict rules. Then you have the people who decide your fate, are you ready to debut? If you do, GREAT! You succeeded. But the fight doesn’t stop there, you still have to compete with other groups, it’s a race to the top. Idols are supposed to follow strict rules, they have to train hours and hours just to make the performance perfect. They have to endure the pain and tiring hours. They have to remain “squeaky-clean”, scandal-less and practically perfect. Some idols even do diets that include eating only a few things a day. Some starve themselves. I know that being an idol is tough. I mean, some members from BTS almost fainted and collapsed due to exhaustion. I’m going to be honest, I think that the K-Pop industry is a little too extreme, but I am willing to try it. This is the only dream that I have been this passionate about. I recently quit my dance studio after attending it for one year. But for that one year, I never felt like I was good enough, yes, I was the youngest and smallest one there, I had the least experience, but I never felt like I belonged there. I was never confident enough. Now, I practice dances by following tutorials (mostly K-Pop dances) and I practice singing by myself. If an audition comes up for the company I would like to be a part of (YG Entertainment), I don’t know how I am supposed to tell my parents. I can’t just all of a sudden tell them, “hey, there is an audition for this company I really wanna be a part of, but it’s in (this country, most likely Korea or Japan), can we PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE book a flight because this is my dream?” No, I can’t just do that, I don’t know if my parents support this (my dad probably doesn’t understand, both my parents would most likely want me to focus on my studies) and they probably think I am too young to do such things. I just turned 13, and there was an application for YG Ent. a few days ago, but I missed it. I don’t know what to do with myself, if I want something SO SO BAD, but I feel like I can’t do it. People say you only live once, and that one life, goes away faster than you think. Even if I do get my head around these things, I don’t know if I can regain my confidence. I don’t know if I can believe in myself enough to do this. I don’t know if I’ll be able to endure all the hours of practise and hard work. But I know that maybe one day, I will be willing to give it a go. I just hope when the time comes, I am not too late.

It’d be really cool, and I might audition a few times just to try it out—if not, it’s alright, but I still think auditioning would be a good opportunity for me. In all honesty, I believe I’d be prepared for all of the things that come with being a K-pop idol, such as the constant training, the chance of being hated and bashed by the public, etc etc. I’m going to go over all the parts of being a K-pop idol and how they’d affect me if I were to actually pursue it. First things first: the beauty standards. Oh, my, the beauty standards are incredibly strict in Korea and many other Asian countries. In some ways, the appearance of an idol can really impact their career more than talent. Here’s a list of the beauty standards in Korea: Slim figure - I have this.Small face - I… think I have this?V-shaped jaw - My jawline is more rounded and not quite what is desired; although, many k-pop idols do have a jawline/shape similar to mine.Small lips - Not quite. Some idols do have my lip shape but, unless I’m mistaken, it is not ideal.Straight eye-brows - Nope, but that could easily be fixed by make-up and/or styling them. They are quite thicc, though.Flawless skin - I thank my mother for the good skin genes—I don’t really have to deal with blemishes or pimples too often.Large eyes - My eyes are in between normal and large, I believe.Double eyelids - Yup!Extremely pale skin - My skin color is light, but not nearly as pale and white as the Korean beauty standard. It looks way lighter in good lighting, but in normal lighting my skin is slightly darker.East Asian - I’m only half Thai, which is technically Southeast Asian, however, it’s more of a problem to be half white in the K-pop industry; I’d probably face some backlash for that. There are half-white K-pop idols, though, such as Seventeen’s Vernon and Momoland’s Nancy.One of my biggest insecurities about my face is my face shape, I think. I wish my jaw was more v-shaped. I guess plastic surgery could fix that, though. Let’s take a look at my face and figure and compare it to the Korean beauty standard:   The Korean beauty standard:  My figure (I’ve used these pictures before in an answer):    gags at the promise ring on my finger man I regret that relationship— Oh, sorry, where were we? Right, here’s what the ideal body is for a K-pop idol.  Eh, pretty close. Although, my Thai relatives said they think I’m fat, but oh well. Next up: talent/ability. K-pop idols are usually expected to have a combination of these skills, although not necessarily all of them when you’re first auditioning: Singing - I think I’m pretty good at singing. It could use work, though, so with a lot of effort, practice, and a good vocal coach, I think I could be really good.Rapping - Well… rapping isn’t exactly my strong suit; I’m definitely not going to be the next L.E. or Jessi or something, but I can see myself being the sub-rapper of a group if needed. In the ironic words of my best friend from my old state, who got me into K-pop, “yOu dOn’T gOt thAt sWaGgER, nAm-sAyin’ hOmiE”Dancing - I used to be in my school’s drama club, where we had to sing and dance at the same time, and I could pick up the choreography pretty quickly. I don’t think I’d have any problems training in a dance studio setting.If I were to be in a K-pop girl band, I’d probably prefer being a vocalist over a rapper, simply because that’s what my voice is more comfortable with and more used to. If my dancing skills improved, and my visuals are way better in the future, then center dancer would be cool, too. But of course, that’s a stretch, there are few idols that can pull off being talented at all three—but they’re out there! ANDDDD CONCLUSION: It is extremely, extremely difficult to become an idol. The chances of me making the auditioning or even debuting is very slim, which is why I might just pursue a singing career here in America—it’s just as difficult, but there won’t be language barriers. Of course, I’m gonna think things through, and wait until I’m older to figure out what I want to do with my… idol career, and such.

response.answer_text: You can. However, it will be hard. Entertainments mainly look for people who are from an asian decent, and look asian. Yes there is a black female idol, Alex Reid from Rania, but it won’t be as easy for those who are non-asian as it was for Alex. The Korean industry is infamous for its slight bias on asians. If you are really serious about becoming an idol, then why not? Annually, many entertainments hold auditions around the world. The main locations are: America, Australia and of course South Korea itself. You can audition with whatever, singing, dancing etc. You must be prepared to literally give yourself up, and dedicate everything to becoming a Kpop Idol. You will be competing against many other trainees, some who have been in the industry for a while, others newbies just like you, all aspiring for just one thing, to become an idol. Entertainments will expect you to practice day and night for hours on end, while also fitting in lessons (if you are still in the education process), singing/dancing practice, composing/producing music, and don’t forget you’ll be rivalling with other trainees. You will be put on a strict diet, to meet the standard of Korean beauty. If you are in a position where it will be hard for you to move to South Korea, and participate in the activities that a normal trainee would. No worries, entertainments are very desperate for trainees so they would invest in everything that you need to be brought to you. A dance teacher, singing teacher, trainer, staff and more. They will pay for this all. In conclusion, the Kpop Industry is like a battlefield. There will be many obstacles, and only the best come out alive. So if you’re ready to fight and determine that place as an idol, go for it.

I’ve been working in and out of some companies and to be completely honest, the idea of being a kpop idol is a little exaggerated. The fame is of the practically 1%. However, the idea is still nice. I’ve coached around 200 trainees but have only coached around 20 personally. The stress is a lot but the determination in some of them is surprising. The thought of debut is enough to encourage people to go beyond their limits and it’s truly amazing. I’m 22 and when I was 15, I was a accepted into - - Entertainment as a trainee. At the time, I truly wanted to become a kpop star and I would stay up for up to 2 days to practice. It sounds cruel but if you have the right mindset. I guess the deciding factor is your motive. WHY do you want to become an idol? Fame? Wealth? I wanted to inspire people and hope that when they saw my performances, I’d make them happy and have hope because I don’t come from a privileged background. I kept that mindset and trained for two years. However, I was still counted as a resident in the United States and had applied to college and chose to go to college in the states instead of pursuing my dream. Why? Because I realized even though my dream sounded nice, in the inside, it was still because I wanted to be known. I was bullied from elementary school til I left to train and my underlying motive I found was to prove the bullies wrong. It wasn’t to make people happy; it was to make people feel bad instead. I’m glad I didn’t pursue my first dream. Now I work alongside with potential kpop idols and I still inspire them to pursue their dreams because I lived mine. Fortunate enough, I still can perform in front of people and make them feel good when they master a routine.

To be honest, no When i was younger, around 7-8, i got into kpop, my 1st ever kpop group was girls generation, they are my role models and i look up to them alot. I would always dance to thier songs and stuff like that, the idol life seemed nice, but that was because i was young, and i did not know that much of it. When i was around 12-13, that was when i really thought of becoming a kpop idol. I thought it would be the coolest thing in the world, i thought since im a pretty good dancer and have decent visuals i could maybe make it in, but looking back, i think my head was up in the clouds a bit too much and never considered what the consequences would be. Now that i am 15, i do not want to, there still is a teny tiny bit of me that wants to, but i usually shut down the fact with a check of reality. The thing is, i do not think foreigners would fit into kpop. Im sorry if this breaks your little dream, but its true, it won't work out, there is very little chance of it happening. Companies usually only accept asians and asians ONLY. Know, i KNOW there are non korean/Asian idols out there today and some that were in it back then, but if you look at it closely, its not working out. Alex from raina left cause it was too much for her, that one French girl in a kpop group was never heard from again, and in general, foriegners can make a debut, but their popularity isn't the strongest it would be, because they are forgieners, they aren't asian, they aren't korean, it does not workout. Back to my example, i acutally auditioned when i was 13 for a well known korean company, and to my suprise, i got a email after auditioning. Looking back i am glad i did not accept, the kpop idol life is extremely hard, i would not keep up with it at all. I am glad i have my freedom and can do what i want without people judging me for who i am or what my face looks like. I am korean/mexican mix, my grandma is Korean (on moms side) and my grandpa was mexican. I could have been a kpop idol, but thank god i turned the offer down. Tbh people who want to become kpop idols and are not asian or korean are a bit delusional to me. If you REALLY REALLY want to become an artist, then become it in your country, no need to go to a whole different country to be an artist, its worthless, it won't work out, face reality, your not korean, your not asian, even if you do get accepted, the training process is extremely hard, and you don't even know if your going to make it into a group. Your popularity wont be that high unLESS you come out of the big 3. To all kpop fans out there that want to become a idol, think about you, your health, your family, friends, etc.. is it really worth it? Is it? To loose all your privileges due to a dream that is too far our of your grip? Think about it, and make sure you have a taste or reality when thinking. Just cause your unnie lana did it, does NOT mean you are going to be able to do it too. Make sure you go through the question once, twice, and thrice if needed to. If you are really hardheaded and think you can genuinely make it, then go for it, just make sure to think about the consequences your little dream will have on you and all the people around you.

Yes. Let’s take a look and see if I fit the Korean beauty standards or not. Slim Figure I am pretty skinny, but I don’t know if I’m skinny enough (I’m 5’3.5 and I weigh 102.8 lbs). If I had to diet, I would probably just eat small amounts of food for breakfast, lunch, and dinner and exercise a lot (I’ll be practicing a lot so that should count). Small Face Eh kinda, but my forehead is kinda big V-shaped jaw No, but there are idols out there who have succeeded without a v-shaped jaw Small/plump lips my lips are thin and heart shaped straight eyebrows my eyebrows are mostly straight with a little arch flawless skin i have sorta bad acne since i’m 14 and since i have freckles, i’ll use some natural remedies to lighten them larger eyes/aegyo-sal i have doe eyes and double eyelids in conclusion, i look average but not ugly. how about my skills? vocal: i’ve been taking vocal classes since june 2018. by now i’d say i could be a lead or sub vocalist dance: i’ve been taking dance lessons on and off since i was six but i plan to take more in my sophomore year. someone told me i am a very expressive dancer. rap: i’m not the best rapper, i haven’t taken any lessons even though there’s a low chance i could get into an agency due to me not having a lot of Asian blood (12.5% Japanese), what if i actually got into an agency and got to train? first of all, that would be super hard, but i still want to go and see for myself. i’m not the type to give up easily, but i would give up if i really(x100) had to, like if i started to feel suicidal or i developed really poor health conditions. i know the training won’t be easy. i’ll have to eat, practice, sleep, repeat. IMO, being able to debut and succeed is all based on luck. the non-asian idols we have now were lucky enough to train and debut, but not lucky enough to succeed in Korea. idols who are white like me (Lana, majority of UHSN, Unionwave’s Miriam and Nia, O My Jewel’s Sophia, and EXP Edition) give me hope that I could debut if I’m lucky enough, but what makes me doubt myself is the fact that most international fans are going to be pressed because I have white privilege. Just like Lana, I could also see myself probably getting accused of having surgery to look Korean since I have 12.5% Japanese ethnicity. Or maybe they won’t be able to tell, I don’t know. All that I know, if I’m talented and or lucky enough to debut, people are going to hate on me because I am Not half or full Asian andWhite privilegedI’m not trying to colonize kpop with my whiteness, okay? Like I said, I have white privilege so my chances at getting into an agency are higher but not as high as half Asians. It’s hard but I try to ignore the non-Koreans who say “K-pop is only for Asians you koreaboo.” IMO, anyone can be a K-pop idol if they can sing, dance, or rap and in Korean, but not in Koreaboo style. No “oNiOnHaSeYo OpPaR” “sArAnG mE jUsEyO,” etc. I bet the people who speak like that are just in it to meet their oppars and become a Y/N. Until I decide I don’t want to be a K-pop idol anymore, I will continue working hard by improving my skills in dancing and singing and learning Korean so I can maybe get into an agency.

yay you! anyone can be an idol, but it’s extremely difficult. first, audition for either the big 3 (YG, SM, JYP - JYP is the nicest) or a smaller company like happyface ent (has dreamcatcher). i wouldn’t recommend pledis or cube because they’re known for mistreatment. i’m using JYP as an example since i have auditioned twice. JYP likes natural idols (no two faced), uniqueness, obviously skill, and looks (but they don’t care as much as say…SM). don’t sing a language you are not familiar with. if you manage to pass the auditions (which would be difficult), you’ll have to have a second audition either in korea (they might pay, but be aware that you might have to pay too). if you pass that… according to an ex SM trainee, basketballs were dropped on their stomach to “strengthen them”. so if your passion is always at 100%, you’re eager to improve, are happy for monthly body and skill evaluations, will know to not talk back, you are happy to train from basically 5/6am - 1–2am every day (yes, am to am) with sometimes no meals and school in between, potentially get trainee debt which you’ll have to pay pack if you debut or if you terminate your trainee contract, face the potential of not being paid fairly or at all (X1 hasn’t been paid a single cent yet) and will always keep in the back of your mind that you could train for years and not debut at all in the end, you’ll begin training. i assume you don’t know korean, so you’ll have to learn that and your traineeship will go for longer. think you can take your time? lisa from blackpink almost didn’t debut because she didn’t learn quick enough. trainee contracts take around 2–5 years? (stray kids’ bang chan trained for approximately 7 years). if you successfully complete your training and debut, yay! don’t forget me when you’re famous.

Do you want to become a K-pop idol? When I was a kid, I had aspirations of being a famous dancer/singer with any one of the two troupes I was a member of. I wrote songs, I modeled for a minute, won a talent show with one troupe, even dealt to some extent, with an up and coming music producer. He had no chance of getting us any real work, so we ditched him. I continued to perceive the world as my eventual moneymaking playground, planning to take it over one day. If that same kid were somehow transported to this day and age, with his lust for stardom, I might have wanted to become a K-pop idol. I wouldn't listen to anyone telling me I couldn't do it. I would ignore the same racial divides you guys do, and hold onto a distant hope of making it. Somehow. And I'd learn the value of experiencing failure at a young age. I'd never make it to South Korea, hell I'd doubtfully even learn Korean. JYP and friends would watch my videos long enough to compose a suitable rejection letter and move on. This would happen to me over and over again until I faced facts. Suddenly, I'd pay more attention. “There are no black K-pop idols,” I'd say to myself. And I'd wonder what that was about. Finally, I'd see that my parents were right. The things I read on the internet were true. The starving, the disbanding groups, the small percentage of success. Going to South Korea would stop making any sense. Slowly, I would come to realize that it was all a dream and nothing more. And I would come up with something more practical and logical. If I was working in TV, which is probable, I'd meet BTS some years later. They'd show up for an interview on some show I was working on in NYC. I would be pretty excited to meet them as they got back together for a special comeback event. After the show, I'd step up to them and introduce myself. “Man, you guys were great. I was a really big fan growing up.” I'd take a pic with them, post it on Facebook, and go back to work. Okay bye.

YES. I would love to become a K-pop (or C-pop) idol. I love singing and dancing and am okay at both. I have tried to audition before and am very aware about the dark sides of the industry. Despite my many attempts at auditioning for all kinds of companies and shows (Idol School, Kpop Star, SM Entertainment, JYP Entertainment, Source Music and more), I have not gotten past the initial round of auditioning. It is terribly devastating, but I have accepted my fate. I do not think it is because of my ethnicity (I am ABC aka American Born Chinese) or my age (I auditioned from 13–15) or even my talent (tbh, there are idols that I can out sing and dance) that I failed to get in. It is because of my face. It is a fact I am well aware of and okay with. After all, I can only learn to love my face (or I could fix it, but I don’t want to). Even now, if I am guaranteed a spot in a girl group, I would drop everything immediately and go. I would leave my comfortable life here, and go live in that starving, impoverished, desperate, judgmental, exhausted world if I could debut. But I can’t. And I am alright with that. When I was obsessed with becoming an idol, a little voice in the back of my mind always said, “But don’t you want to be a normal human? Don’t you want to have a steady job, a quiet life, and be able to marry without receiving hate?” And I do. I am not a loud or extravagant person. I would enjoy a quiet life. I do want to get married early enough to safely have a child or two. I want to have a healthy body. I want to have a steady income and job. I want both lives at once, and I have only chosen the more realistic side. It still is not too late for me. I still am only 16 years old. I still sing and dance as a hobby, and every time I see idols performing, I wish I could too. I couldn’t watch Kpop Star or Idol School or even Produce 101. Even if I see a clip, I feel the urge to start again. To audition more. But I will not. And I cannot. And even though I had not ever entered the industry, I have learned a few things. I am, firstly, much more appreciative of idols. I also am able to tolerate idols’ a lot more. I think I will be able to live my life much more happily and more positively then if I had never had such a dream.

When I was 13 and just got into KPOP, I probably have answered with no hesitation "YES, DUH!" Now that I've grown up and realized how fragile I am, the answer would be with no hesitation "Heck no." As a Chinese American teenager, to go into a country that has a relatively homogenous society and thus would have a hard time assimilating, to go into a system that criticizes your looks and your weight, to be expected to be forgo all sleep to practice singing and dancing, not see your family for the years that you're a trainee and even after you debut, live with girls that you've teamed up with because maybe you're musically or visually compatible and not necessarily socially compatible, not be able to pursue any romance, are expected to be positive all the time, have to put up with stalker fans and paparazzi, etc.  I've never been skinny and have a poor digestive system. To be suggested that I should eat only one food item per day is offensive to me, as well as possibly dangerous. I have flat feet, weak ankles, and weak knees. Dancing in high heels, let alone walking, for more than one night a month is asking for trouble. Suggestions that I should get plastic surgery to increase chances of debut would probably cut in my self-esteem to the point it would be impossible to restore it. If I debuted, the fact that I grew up in a foreign society and can easily misunderstand and be misunderstood could definitely cut against the popularity that my career depends upon, and the anxiety of living with that would probably affect my health. Also considering that super long contracts are common, making my agency was treating me fairly would add on to my worries.  And this is assuming I even get through auditions or casted.  To me, all the hardships I described above aren't worth any of the fame. I also don't have a strong desire to be a singer, or the dream to be an artist. So, I have so much respect for Kpop Idols for braving such an arduous path to pursue their dreams.

Not at all. I love K-Pop. Unlike many Western artists, K-Pop idols are expected to be squeaky clean, and I'm not just talking about their appearances here. They have to be scandal-free, well-mannered, and more importantly, well-rounded. K-Pop idols are basically like a breeze of clear air amidst the stormy, scandalous Western artists. I really appreciate the works and efforts they need to invest in order to mold those traits. In a nutshell, K-Pop idols are meant to appeal as the ideal type of boyfriends/girlfriends you’d like to have. But how much you'd have to sacrifice in order to get there? As a trainee, you're required to fulfill some strict trainings. You need to master at the very least one subject whether it's singing or rapping, but your dancing skill will still need to be above average because K-Pop idols are all about audiovisual. I do have some experiences with dancing, but I don't think I have enough drive to spend years of my life learning choreography. You will have to compete with your friends, until the company decides that you're good enough to debut. Even after you debut, the competition doesn't end there since you already have so many other extremely talented sunbaenims currently battling their way up into the top charts. Your personal life is very restricted as fans can be very obsessed with you; some might be crazy enough to become a Sasaeng. Sure, there are a few K-Pop Idols who are lucky enough to be able to date peacefully and even marry the person they love like BigBang (their fans are mostly older than most fans nowadays, so they're basically much more mature and open minded), but what if Kim Taehyung of BTS suddenly tells the ARMYs that he's engaged? His fiancee’s life could be in danger, his whole career could meet an instant end. I don't think I can live in such environments. The K-Pop industry is a life that can only be endured by the people with exceptional skills and extreme determinations. I'd prefer to be here, writing answers on Quora, living a life of my own without anyone closely monitoring my activities, or a bunch of fans trying to get some close up photos of my face at the airports.

So for introducing I am Kim seoulhyun. I am half korean and half Spanish and I really want to be a kpop idol. I was a trainee at a non big three company. When I was 14 I was a trainee for a year or so and then I left. Trainee life is hard . I trained in dancing for 8 years and in singing for 7 years. I learnt korean in 3 months. There were 20 girls in one room I think. we had to get up at 5:00 am in the morning in breakfast we used to eat nothing except 2 sweet potato by 7 the trainees used to go to their school. My school gets over at 2:00pm and I reach at the company in an half hour or so . From 3:00 to 4:30 their were language classes which includes Japanese, Chinese and lastly korean(for non- Koreans ) then 15 min break from 4:45 to 6:45 there was gym and fitness classes after that 7:00 to 9:30 there were vocal classes and 9:45 to 12 was our dance classes. After that we used to eat dinner which was chicken breast and a low fat yogurt. The only snacks we were allowed to have was fruits. We weren’t allowed to meet our parents. I also became extremely skinny and the company thought that I wasn’t pretty enough to debut in their group ( not taking any names ) I had serve depression too and my mental health kept getting worse so I decide to leave the company well I am 16 now a year I left the company and I am now doing better. Here’s my pic for the reference     Edit: Thank you so much for the upvotes 🥺💜

Yes, I really do, but at the same time, I really don’t. i desperately want to get that kind of experience but if I debut, I’m scared. Because I’m not Asian, I’m scared nobody will support me and people will tell me I’m trying to be something I’m not (Asian). I am not, nor have I ever been, a Koreaboo, or any kind of Asia-boo. I accept who I am and I’m happy with it. Actually “do I want to be a K-pop idol” is a question that’s always in the back of my head. I think about it so much, it can be exhausting. It’s a constant argument with myself. Reasons why I want to The first reason was I saw the friendships that K-pop idols had with each other and I want to experience it.Fansigns. I love the idea of hi-touch and meeting fansI think that training would be good for me and a good experienceI have the talent. I’ve been singing all my life and I’m really good at it. I’ve also picked up rapping and I’m decent at that as well. I’m good at learning choreography but I’m not that good at dancing and I’m kind of stiff, but in terms of rapping and vocals I’m good enough and I’m not being arrogant, because I’ve been told this on multiple occasionsI have the 4d personality and want to show people a “real” person in K-popI want to inspire peopleI love Korean language and want to experience itI want to live with my members, and I want to be so close to themI want people to admire me and look up to me and learn to accept me beyond my raceI’m ready to work hardI’m semi-fluent in Korean alreadyreasons why I don’t want to I feel like nobody will support me, no matter how much talent and potential I haveI’m scared that I won’t end up being good enough because people will have such a high expectation of me if I’m not asianI’m scared that people will assume things like I’m a koreabooThere’s more but I want to wrap this up because I’m so hungryyy lolabout me Yes, I am a white girl. Yes, I feel sad occasionally because it’d be so much easier for me if I was Asian and could achieve my dreams without as much backlash. But I don’t want to be Asian. I want to show talent, become independent, inspire people, have fans, make lifelong friendships, improve my skills, debut in a group, perform my life away, and have fun whilst working among people I love. I want to experience those hardships and if those hardships are harder than they would be if I was Korean or Asian at all, then so be it. I’ll work through them and work harder and become a better person. I am not a Koreaboo. A Koreaboo is someone who wants to be Korean. I don’t want to be Korean. I want to be myself. Anyways… To sum it up, I want to be a K-pop idol, but I’m scared that nobody would support me… yeah thanks for reading this far lmao

response.answer_text: I would, yes. But I’m quite… Alright, so let’s start with my face, and what people would expect a Kpop idol to look like. Compared to them, my face isn’t as clear as them even if they have no makeup. My eyes are pretty small, and look like about two centimeter slits on my eyes. My nose is a little bigger than what fans would want it to be. My lips are probably the only things I actually like about my body in general. They are full lips, even though idols usually have small lips. Still love my lips~ <3 Dieting is also a thing that I would have to go through. I would rather die than not eat properly for 5 months. Anyways, I think that my body is fine just the way it is. But just in case I just lose my skinniness, I would have to be eating improperly. Also, training before you actually debut can be nerve-wracking. You can be cut even though you haven’t even had a chance to debut in that company. The question is, would you really want to train 12 hours a day, and barely have enough sleep just because we didn’t get this specific part right, so we have to train extra hours? You have to go through very strict critiques almost everyday. Being able to sing, rap, or dance is also something that you have to be pretty good at. You’d be very lucky if you got accepted even if the only thing you’re good at is standing there, no visuals, no skills, nothing. I wish life would be like that… Then I would’ve been an idol a while ago, just doing nothing.. ;-; Technically, you would have to have the actual talent or visuals to be an idol. You’d have to be able to pick up quickly, and fix it. The Korean language is also something you have to know. Studying the language would probably help you, and it’ll be better if I were Korean. I don’t know actually, to be honest, at this point, I’m just being mean to myself. wE hAvE tO hAnDlE tHe PrEsSuRe ToO

Personally speaking, seeing how the life of a K-Pop idol is sometimes tempts me to drop my studies and train instead. More than usual though, I'm your average homebody with a passion for the arts in general, and seeing how broad and expansive and difficult their life would be, my mental health wouldn't take it. Being a K-Pop idol is different for everyone: you want to sing, or you want to dance, or you want to try out the concepts in groups, or even for more personal reasons. It takes a lot of training in at least 3 languages, vocal training, dancing, and monthly spiels/talents for showcases. I can also see there's a difficult seniority system and plausibly cultural differences to boot, and undeniably factions with other trainees. Pre-debut process by itself is like a double-edged life. There's also the uncertainty of whether you'll debut or get cut due to finances/etc. If I took the chance to audition for this, I have to guarantee my will to make something out of it is more than my constant disappointment at not being good enough for it. I have to constantly tell myself the long road is worth it for the stage I would hold for minutes, and just minutes to show that lengthy experience. Being a K-Pop idol also takes a lot of patience, because not everyone makes it big, and not everyone can handle promoting for a month in music shows, and it's a common path to hold busker events in populated areas to gain recognition for it. You might also be envious for an idol gaining fame from a viral video, or for any other thing that can happen. But when that sweet time comes, invitations for CFs and variety shows would pour, advertisements and radio show offers are in your reach, knowing there's a steady stream of fans in offical fancafes and seeing their comments is energizing. And like what my long-time favorite girl group has confessed for their tenth anniversary, they acknowledge that they wouldn't have made it this far without their fans, because ultimately, if they didn't have any, they'd be nothing. A lot of bad and good things can happen for someone to want to be a K-Pop idol. There's no generic reason for it (or at least, in my perspective), so here's my take on it.

There isn’t much in good at. I’m a performer in a family of scientists, doctors and lawyers because I’m not smart. The only things I’m good at are performing and helping people to feel better when they’re struggling. I’ve done a lot of thinking and I can’t think of anything better suited for me than being a kpop idol. Why ??? I could easily stay in the UK being a backup dancer or on the West End doing plays or musicals, so why specifically a kpop idol ??? It’s the influence they have mixed with the concepts. Looking at the less serious side I guess I’d love to be a kpop idol for the fun choreography they do and the catchy songs they sing. You could have any concept from bubblegum pop to girl crush. I love all of it !!! Being able to do something and being proud of it is something’s I’ve always wanted. People don’t take you seriously when you say you want to be a performer in the UK because it’s an unstable and unpredictable job but honestly I don’t care, I want to show that there is something I’m good at and be proud of it. There’s no happier time for me than being on stage with all of my friends. Next, the influence. I mentioned before that the only things I’m good at are performing and I’ve thought a lot of how I can help people feel better when performing and the only thing I can think of is a kpop idol. I could always be a singer here in the UK, but there are not a lot of chances to work in a group which is something I do better at, soloists are way more prominent but that’s not what I want. Anyway, the West isn’t into smol and cute girls like me so nobody would want me to be a solo singer in the UK because I don’t fit their standards. I think being in a group suits me better as being surrounded by people makes my ‘look after other people’ instincts kick in, whether it’s the people I’m working with or the people that I’m in front of. I want to be someone with influence so that I can be a positive influence to people and also be a source of comfort for others. Kpop idols have A LOT of influence over their fans who are very dedicated and I want to be able to use that to mine and other people’s advantage. Another reason I’d prefer to be in a group is because I’m incredibly shy and being around people I trust brings out the best in me. I feel like I’m being bigheaded and too hopeful in this post which isn’t like me. It’s not like I’ll ever actually be a kpop idol anyway. I’m probably too old at this point (2000 line) and I’m only half Asian (Chinese/ English) so I’m not actually hopeful at all. I guess I’ll just stick with backup dancing instead.

Short answer: No. Long answer: Okay, let’s take a look at a K-pop idol’s life. First, trainee years: Trainees usually train for at least 2 years before they debut. Some may even extend up to 7 years. They’ll work very hard to improve their singing, dancing or rapping skills. Not only that, some idols are forced to go to unhealthy diet to achieve perfect bodies, which often results to idols fainting on stage and the like. After they debut: Okay, so you have debuted, and you received thousands of love and recognition for your talent. Cool. But no matter how talented you are, you cannot please everybody, and even if you’re not doing anything bad, you will still gain hate from other people, who usually eventually become anti fans. From what I observed since I entered the K-pop world, K-pop fans/anti fans are crazier than normal fans. In South Korean culture, we have sasaengs. Sasaengs are fans (though I don’t really classify them as fans) who are crazily (literally) obsessed with their idols that they will do whatever it takes to get noticed by their idols. Common examples of sasaeng activities are invading their idol’s privacy e.g. breaking into their house and stealing their personal properties and in some cases, putting up a secret recorder, tracking their cars, sending them blood-written letters, etc. Is that something I would want to happen to me as a K-pop star? NO. Another thing: schedules. K-pop stars’ schedules are so hectic that some barely get enough rest and suffer of sleep deprivation. Some agencies also tend to overwork their idols and do not prioritize their health coughSMcough, resulting to idols fainting or attaining injuries (usually leg injuries). And even if you have injuries, that doesn’t exempt you from performing on stage (e.g. EXO). Thankfully BigHit takes care of their idols well. Let’s not forget that there are other agencies which are left in a huge debt when their idols aren’t as successful as they hope so, and eventually end up disbanding the group. Hip hop girl group The Ark is an example, which is too bad because they were unlike any other girl group. So these are just some of the reasons why I wouldn’t want to be a K-pop star. I could add more to the list but it would get too long.

A big reason is a passion for music or dance and for performing- getting to be on stage, hear the audience screaming, getting to convey your message to thousands of people and be recognized. After all, people spend years training in music and dancing under difficult conditions, and though everything else that comes with being an idol (like variety shows, acting, modeling, etc.) may also be part of their goal, if they didn’t have the passion for music and dance, they wouldn’t have made it through those years of training. Another major reason is that idols are able to reach lots of people through things other than music, such as variety shows, acting, vlives, etc. Being an idol is more than just singing and dancing- a lot of it is about fan interaction. And personally, watching kpop idols never fails to make me laugh- their personalities are a huge part of idol life, and they are really funny and kind and overall great people who make other people happy. And if you’re a kpop idol, you also have the opportunity to make people happy, and I think that’s pretty great. A simpler reason is just that people want to be famous. People want to do something with their life that is recognized by other people and want to die having left their mark on the world. Another simple reason is just that it looks fun- at least on screen. It’s easy to get drawn in by their compelling lifestyles and charming personalities, and though there are dark sides to idol life and kpop, for the most part idols are happy with their lives and their jobs. (Or at the very least, they look happy.) So you see someone on screen who is happy, doing what they want to do in life, with the same passion for music as you do, and you think “Wow, I want to be like them”, because at the end of the day, people want to be happy. This next reason pertains mostly to people living in Korea, though I’m not an expert on Korean culture, so please correct me if there are any inaccuracies. But basically, what I’ve heard is that everything in Korea is very competitive in terms of school and extracurriculars and whatever else they do. Most people, after they go to school, will then go to extra school in order to get ahead of everyone else (except everyone does this, so basically it’s a race to see who can prep the most. Prep classes are also part of the culture among Asian Americans as well, but it’s a lot bigger in Korea.) So everyone is working really hard to get ahead of everyone else, people who are working just as hard as them and putting in just as much extra time and effort. So though training to be a kpop idol is really hard, going the traditional school route isn’t that much better. (Though it probably is easier, as you only have one thing to focus on whereas trainees have to train and continue to keep up with their schoolwork at the same time.) So if you know you’re really passionate about music or dancing, why would you want to spend so much time and effort on school when you could just become a trainee? Yeah, it’s a more difficult life, but it gets you out of the school track and lets you pursue what you’re passionate about, so it’s not a bad tradeoff. Another point is specifically pertaining to kpop idols who came from the US. Due to stereotypes it’s pretty hard for Asian American artists to be popular in America. And even if they were popular, I feel like they’d also be the butt of a lot of “Asian” jokes. A lot of people would see them more for their ethnicity than for their music (like “wow! an Asian artist! how unusual!”) and attribute some of their success to their ethnicity. And that feeling sucks, honestly. I wouldn’t want to live with that feeling hanging over my head all the time. But in Korea, even though they might not completely fit in, foreign idols are pretty common and other people wouldn’t see them as anything particularly unusual. Of course, there are a million other reasons why someone would want to be a kpop idol, but I think these are the major ones.

It’ll be the ultimate dream for many of the K-POP fans, including myself. I mean, you’re probably going to be known all over the world, fame will always be with you, you’ll have a blast at concerts and promoting and you’d dancing and singing to your heart’s content! Em no. For all of you fans, you could be passionate for dancing or singing or you could just be deluded, but really you need to see how hard it is to be an idol. It takes a lot of mental strength, physically endurance and most importantly the will of iron. It takes so much dedication and you have to pour your blood, sweat and tears into all you practice to hone your skills, just to show your potential to managers. Dieting will be common and it’ll be harsh to the point you’ll faint in the middle of practice. They’ll groom you until you’re close to the beauty standards of Korea. Dancing until your legs give up and you’re sweating buckets. Singing and rapping until your voice goes hoarse. All of these situations could happen and are quite commonly heard from ex-trainees. I’ve seen some young teenagers who are completely engrossed in the world of K-POP and really want to be an idol but they’ve completely ignored the suffering and misery that you’d suffer from being a trainee. Hopefully these kids will grow up and expand their horizons and truly see the outlook of the many retired trainees and see why they gave up. To the bottom line, being a trainee is not rainbows and unicorns all day, it’s renowned for the rigorous and demanding training that people tend to overlook. It’s not for the faint hearted.

Once upon a time, I did. I'm still occasionally tempted, but I know I will never follow through with it. Everyone on this thread has talked about the dark sides of the industry. The self harm, the eating disorders, the harsh words of keyboard warriors, and lack of mental health support. I will bring a different perspective. You may never see your family until a few years. Especially from a foreigner trainee's standpoint. If that's your case, slim down that chance to almost none, unless you become extremely famous (ex: BLACKPINK's Lisa), but that almost never happens. For example, Mark from NCT said one time that he hasn't visited his family in years. He went at least four years without going home to Canada. Think about it. You will never get to see your little sibling grow up, or your older sibling go to college or get married. You will become a stranger to your extended family because you never attend family gatherings anymore. Your grandparents may pass, and you'll never get the chance to say goodbye. And most importantly, your parents will never see you for years. Do you think they can handle that? Can you handle being away in another country without ever being able to see them? Not being able to talk to them? Being a trainee is so busy, that you won't often be able to call or text them. You must also take time zones into consideration. Is it fair to rarely call your parents unless it's 3AM in the morning for them? Besides, if you're unlucky enough, that might not even be an option for you. Some companies never allow trainees to own a phone. Additionally, when your parents get old, you'll never be able to take care of them the way they deserve to be cared for. If you're not close with your family, think about your friends. Once again, if you don't live in Seoul, you might as well kiss your best friend goodbye. You'll never see them ever again. Friendships almost never survive if you're not living in close areas. Your friend group will learn to forget about you and move on. Truthfully, almost no teenager (I'm assuming most aspiring idols are in this age group) would be willing to stay long distance friends with you. Or alternatively, if they do, your friendship will not remain exactly the way it was before you left to become a trainee. How could it? I'm sure if the roles were reversed and they were the one who left, you would act just as distant. You won't be able to laugh and talk behind the back of your annoying history teacher with your classmates. You'd be in another country, in another school. You'd be training for at least ten hours. Adding your hours of study to that, and you'd have almost no time for sleep. How could you possibly be energetic enough in the morning to befriend your classmates? Additionally, if you have a language barrier because you don't speak Korean, you might not be able to make friends anyway. If you do, is there even a point in making friends? You'll be training the moment class ends. There's no time to hang out, go shopping or eat out with friends like a regular teenager. In conclusion, making the decision to become a trainee is a lot more selfish than you realize. I hope anyone who considers going into the industry considers these points. Thanks for reading.

Fame, money, and glory. They think being an idol is easy and fun. What many don’t know is that becoming an idol is actually an extremely stressful process that includes extreme dieting, non-stop practice, no free time, and a contract that often makes it extremely difficult to earn any money for yourself. There are many challenges: Physically, you must fit height requirements, have no excess fat at all, be good-looking, and must be East Asian.Talent wise, you must have a strong dancing background and either sing or rap well to even audition.If you pass auditions, you become a trainee, meaning you don’t get to see your friends and family anymore, and your entire live revolves around dancing, singing/rapping, working out, dieting, and taking Korean lessons if you don’t speak Korean.Trainees often fall into depression or give up partway through because of the difficult lifestyle. Even if you endure, it usually takes several years before you debut in a group.Even if you debut, it’s unlikely that you’ll hit fame at all, unless you come from SM, YG, or JYP Ent (the big 3 companies). But in that case, you’ll have a horrible contract that doesn’t let you make money and a company that treats you like a tool and not a person.Whether or not your group becomes famous, the first few years of having no fans will be physically and emotionally taxing. When you do become famous, you become richer, but physically, it gets even harder.Famous idols must always stay fit and often go on diets. They also travel all the time for tours and shows, and rarely get breaks. Often, they go on only a few hours of sleep before performing for hours on stage.

The age old question. How can I become a kpop idol? Learn Korean/Hangul- I’d say a very basic step. Work EXTRA HARD on speaking (pronunciation) and understanding.Gain basic knowledge on singing. Specifically work on how to Support. There is this guy named Ahmin and he gives tips for K-Pop fans on how to learn to sing. Also, visit K-Pop vocal analysis so that you can see what makes a good singer and a bad singer. Once you got all of the BASIC technique of singing down feel free to listen to a K-Pop vocalist you might like and try to follow their stylistic singing choices.Learn the basics of dance. This might be a thing where you have to attend hip hop class every week. Or, if you’re extremely talented- watch a bunch of YouTube videos on basic dance technique. You also MUST learn how to freestyle.Extra step: Learn how to rap. The basics YOU NEED TO KNOW are how to have a good flow and how to have emotion in your rap. If you take the rap route, learn how to freestyle rap.Charisma is very important in a K-Pop idol. Learn when to use certain face gestures, learn how to have an enticing smile, and in general learn how to be extremely likable.EXTRA STEPS: Learn another language: Japanese, Mandarin, Thai, etc. Learn how to use a MIDI keyboard and how to write nice lyrics.That’s pretty much the basics that you need to know to succeed in becoming a Kpop idol. Oh, and one more thing, prepare multiple songs, choreographies, etc for your K-Pop audition. Have 2–3 Vocal songs 1–2 Choreographies 2–3 Strong rap bars. Besf of luck in becoming a K-Pop idol!

I had become very sad due to a number of reasons. I didn’t want to eat. I didn’t want to do anything. Once I started listening to their music and following groups, I became happier. I like Kpop music and I admire many Kpop stars, but I would never want to be a Kpop star, even if I was good at singing and dancing. Most Kpop companies tie their trainees and musicians to slave contracts, stripping them of their musical and personal freedom. Many trainees even sign 7–10 year contracts but never debut or accomplish their dreams, so signing with an entertainment company basically means gambling your future. Balancing schoolwork, training, and taking language lessons is more than the average human being can handle. Even if some groups make it to the end and debut, they’re not guaranteed success. The Kpop industry has grown more and more competitive since its peak in the 2000s, and only the best of the best have chances of making it big within a tough place. A lot of groups aren’t even given the freedom to write or compose their own songs. They’re just fed songs by the company, and have to perform like machines, simply for money to keep the business going. In fact, most companies don’t even pay their artists or let them contact their families until their first music show win. It may look fun, watching your favorite groups perform, but underneath their charismatic exteriors lies lost hours of sleeping and eating, and drained souls who can’t live a normal life, away from the spotlight where every one of your actions is targeted by paparazzi and malicious netizens.

It's been a long time, but oh well… Nope. I used to. Not anymore. There's a glamorous and dazzling career we see when we look at kpop artists, and that makes everybody wants to be like them. What we usually don't realize or take into account is the price we'd have to pay to become a part in it. And the risk. Like all entertainment industry, there's a dark side to kpop. One that, no matter how passionate you are about singin/dancing/etc, can catch you so off guard and ruin all that you love. You get a lot of love if you debut, but the hate is judging and unforgiving. I wanted to be a kpop artist. An acquaintance of my mothers told me no. I asked why. She said, there are unmentionable things done to girls there. Not all, but some. It'd be hard pressed to know exactly which agency is clean, which people is true, and which ones to keep away from. Now, in March 2019, I remember my mother's acquaintance and thanked her. I would've been a naive foreign girl alone in a strange place with no safety net easily lured in by kind faces.

I’d probably only become a kpop star if you threatened to kill my family or friends if I didn’t do it. Besides, I’d hate to keep up a fake perfect image of myself in public. Regardless of the fact that trainee life is harsh and that it doesn’t get any easier after debut, think about what you would do after your group disbands. (Because no group will keep going into their 50s. There are younger idols who could easily replace them.) Career options seem pretty limited, especially if you’re not super well known or extremely talented. Not everyone can be a decently popular model or actor, and the chances are even slimmer for someone who’s older and/or doesn’t fit the mold as well. I could be totally wrong, however, since the members of kpop’s 2nd generation are just starting to wrap up their idol activities (Girls Generation, Big Bang, Wonder Girls…) and get jobs outside of the idol sphere. But with what k-entertainment currently has, it seems near impossible that all the mainstream kpop idols in existence will continue their careers in k-entertainment after they finish idol activities.

No, for various reasons. The chances of you debuting is very small. You may end up spending years as a trainee only to not debut. As you grow older, your chances of joining the debut group becomes slimmer and if you don’t make the team then while you decide on a new career, your peers have already graduated college and secured stable jobs.Many trainees are treated poorly and exploited. You need maintain your weight and that often involved unhealthy dieting to keep your figure.If you aren’t Korean, you need to learn a new language, move to a new country, learn and adapt to a different culture, and accept the fact that you will be paid less if you do debut compared to your Korean members although that may change in the future as people are fighting for equal pay for foreign members.Money - unless you are super successful like Big Bang, SNSD, or BoA to name a few, you probably won’t be making much…if any. The company takes a large portion of your pay. Yoona debuted with SNSD a year before Justin Bieber. Her net worth is about $11 million compared to Justin’s $265 million. Yeonwoo from Momoland recently said in a show that the group still hasn’t made any money yet because they are still paying back the debt they accrued as trainees and they’ve debuted for a little over two years now.The list could go on, but I’m going to stop here.
