At this exact moment, I want to become a K-POP idol. For me, music has always been a big part of my life. My grandmother sang, my dad sings and plays 2 instruments and has been in multiple (small) music groups throughout my life, and my sisters and I can sing and play at least one instrument. At one point in my life, I had severe depression and nearly attempted suicide, and music was always my way of coping. I never really clicked with the music in my country, or with my country. As stereotypical as it sounds, I’ve always felt like the weird person who doesn’t belong here, and I have actually been told by my own teacher before that I look like I’m not meant to stay here, like I’m supposed to be somewhere else and do something else. Yes, I am aware of all the risks that come with an idol, including the overworking, dieting, sasaengs, haters/antis, and everything else. Everything in life comes with a risk, so there will always be some danger in my life whether I actually try to become an idol or not. I’ve actually submitted an audition via email to Big Hit Entertainment, although I know that I won’t make it. I’m going to try to audition for other companies in the future, but I’m also trying to work on learning Korean and doing K-POP covers of songs and choreography at the moment.

I would say that the best way is being selected by three top entertainment agencies, which are JYP entertainment, YG entertainment and SM entertainment. To be selected as a trainee at these companies, there are some ways. We have several audition TV shows from different broadcast stations such as ‘Produce101’ from Mnet, ‘Kpop star’ from SBS, ‘Superstar K’, ‘Show me the money’ from Mnet, and I am sure more audition programs will be made. Once you get a spotlight on your talent in that show, judges who are from these companies, will select you as a their trainee. Besides, there are some local auditions too periodically. Visit there website(SMTOWN), there are weekly, monthly auditions even in Japan and USA. These top companies and also other famous companies(Cube, Loen, Jellyfish) have well-made training systems that they have experienced instructors to teach them to sing, dance, act, and all attitudes to be a Kpop star. Their trainees normally spend 3 or more than 5 years to learn and finally can debut. Considering your talent, personality, age, nationality and leadership, you can be a member of a group or solo. Being a Kpop idol is very unique, which is not made by themselves, always big entertainment companies are involved. Compared to singer-songwriters, Kpop idols are not only sining and dancing with songs they make, but they come with perfect choreography, bold & colorful music video, nicely conceptualized theme, and costume. This formula makes the Kpop idol as a big music commodity. These days, there are many ways to show their talent thanks to youtube, personal broadcasting through instagram, you can make your own spotlight. That will be an other way to be selected and debut, but it is hard to imagine to become a Kpop idol without big agencies.

response.answer_text: No. I’ve always wanted to do music, since I was small girl and when I got into kpop I definitely considered it. How amazing wouldn’t it be? It’s hard work and the business is shady at times, there’s no denying that. But despite all the hardships, I still thought “this could be your way into music”. But I’m not a person that would do well on a stage. I don’t like the attention, as simple as that. I dislike the spotlight. I would do much better as a manager or behind the stage, always have been much better behind the stage than on it. So while the hardships are an honest reason to consider twice or thrice or - hell, ten times - it is not really the reason to my no. No, I wouldn’t want to be a kpop idol. But I would very much like to work in the business - behind the scene.

Most of the answers I’ve seen here say that they used to want to but don’t anymore. I’ve never wanted to be a K-pop star, even from the time I first started getting into K-pop. Firstly, I’m artistically talented, not musically talented, and I can barely stand in front of my class and present my project to them. I’d probably faint if I was on stage. Secondly, it’s really hard to learn a new language. I know this because it took me more than a decade to learn English. Besides, K-pop can be more of a curse than a blessing. Even if you make it big, which is already unlikely enough, you still have to deal with all the stress and work. Idols have stated that the average idol only gets 1–4 hours of sleep. And if you are a very well-managed person, then think about this: idols have some basic human rights taken away from them, such as bans on dating, bans on what you eat, slave contracts, bans on seeing your family, forced plastic surgery, etc. It can be too much for some people, point: Jonghyun of SHINee. I respect those who can go through all that, but I definitely wouldn’t wish that lifestyle on anyone.

There is a lot that goes into becoming a k-pop idol. First off, talent. You need to stand out to them with your talent, but they also need to see the potential in you. Otherwise known as being able to see how much they can change your style or improve you with their training. Then there’s looks. Plastic surgery, dieting, and exercising are things that are used to help give you an ideal look. Having charisma is something that some companies look into, like JYP. SM however is known to be more focused on appearance. Learning languages is important as well, and if you don’t know Korean, then you better start learning. There is also the intense amount of stress that you go through. Not everything is sunshine and rainbows. Jonghyun was definitely not one of the happier k-pop idols, and not many of them are. You will find that a lot of them have anxiety, eating disorders, and a lot more. There’s probably more, but these are the biggest parts to it. Hope that this helped. Let me know if you find anything else on it.

I think most companies value looks than talent. Someone that has no experience in singing/dancing/rapping but has the looks has a high chance of getting street casted in Korea. If you have the talent but your looks are lacking, the company might recommend you to get plastic surgery. Companies also looks for talent. Companies reach out to people who catch their eye during competitions. They also hold auditions and those that pass will be accepted to the company as trainees. Stage presence is very important. If you have a lot of talent but fail to capture peoples’ attention you’ll probably be rejected. You also need to have a lot of determination. Entering the company as a trainee is just the start. It was very challenging while being a trainee - monthly evaluations and the fear of really being able to debut or not. Many trainees crack under the pressure and quit their dreams of debuting. Lastly, manners. You don’t want the company representatives to have a bad impression on you. Even if you are able to debut, if you are rude the public will just throw hate to you. I’m not really sure if the last point is true but the first three are definitely correct. Looks and talent are the biggest factors for debut though. Hope this helps!

If you think you have what it takes to take on the idol life then go ahead and audition for different companies. Don’t limit yourself to the big 3 but instead look at other companies that interest you and apply to loads as you might not hear back from half of the companies you audition for.

It takes being really great at some aspect of pop performance - singing, rapping, dancing, stage presence, and/or visual/personality. You need to be decent at most of the others too, and willing to learn. I would now say that writing and production skills are also a big plus at many agencies (YG/JYP/Pledis/BigHit/etc), given the way the industry seems to be developing. More practically, you need to be willing to move to Seoul, learn Korean if you don’t speak it, and train really hard for a few years while still keeping your grades up in school, possibly risking incurring tens of thousands of dollars worth of training debt if you are not at a Big 3 agency. You also probably want to be at least partially east or southeast Asian to debut at a major agency.

The best things to do is just start working out. Kpop idols require lots of stamina such as dancing and singing at the same time which most cannot naturally do. Also practice dancing and complex foot work so you don’t get lost easily, for example pick a piece of choreography and try to perfect in a certain amount of time like a 2 days until you have it down to an hour or less this will make it easily for you in the future. Practicing singing is essential so pull up some voice lessons on YouTube or just keep singing your favourite songs until the pitch in your egisyer becomes easy (still recommend watching some videos so you know what you need to look for). Also if you aren’t fluent in korean better work on that cause it’s extremely important (if you don’t know korean work on singing in your own language) fashion is often picked but it’s important to know how to dress when your outfits aren’t chosen especially if your a foreigner and the fashion is very different. This ties into culture if your a foreigner learn about the culture! ps if your a girl better get used to walking in high heels so just a quick recap staminaendurencedancingsingingkoreanfashionculturewalking in heels
